questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rubeola

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule? Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face. Internal capsule has projection fibers. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The internal capsule is primarily composed of projection fibers that connect the cortex to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. The internal capsule can be divided into three parts: anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. Lesions in these areas can result in different neurological deficits.
  • • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes. The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis. The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits.
  • • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes.
  • • The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis.
  • • The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits.
  • • The retrolenticular part of the internal capsule carries fibers primarily from the optic radiation, which is a bundle of axons that originate from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in this area can result in visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, superior or inferior quadrantanopia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 4 : Internal capsule has projection fibers - The internal capsule contains a large collection of projection fibers that include both ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord, conveying sensory information to the cortex and motor commands away from the cortex.
  • • Statement 4
  • • Internal capsule has projection fibers -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule, a key white matter structure in the brain, contains Charcot's artery-supplied posterior limb, optic radiation in the retrolenticular part, and is primarily composed of projection fibers linking the cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord. Misinformation about the anterior limb's contents highlights the complexity and specificity of its neural pathways.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) hCG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta. hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days. The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.
  • • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. LH : Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.
  • • Option A. LH
  • • Option C. FSH : Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.
  • • Option C. FSH
  • • Option D. GnRH : Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.
  • • Option D. GnRH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 66
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 66

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 328
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 328

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 167

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Reef knot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: The reef knot has
  • ➤ Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”
  • ➤ Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.
  • • Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness:
  • • Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.
  • • Option C. Right sided conductive deafness:
  • • Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.
  • • Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

questions.text: Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? ( INICET NOV 2022) Glutaraldehyde Ethylene oxide Pasteurization Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle

options.label: C
options.text: Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.correct_answer: A. It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method for assessing the success of H. pylori eradication therapy due to its accuracy and convenience.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DNS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.correct_answer: A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • 'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Contraction of right atrium : This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.
  • • Option B. Contraction of right atrium
  • • Option C. Passive filling of right atrium : Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.
  • • Option C. Passive filling of right atrium
  • • Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium : Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.
  • • Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fig : Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x 1 , y= Negative waves
  • ➤ Fig

questions.text: A microbiologist stained a tissue sample and found thin, filamentous bacteria, which resembled Nocardia sp. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the presence of Nocardia? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Modified acid-fast stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The modified acid-fast stain should be used to confirm the presence of Nocardia due to its weak acid-fast nature and characteristic "beaded" appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a breast condition as demonstrated in the image below. This condition is due to invasion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dermal lymphatics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The peau d'orange appearance of the breast is due to blockage of the superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion, leading to edema and the characteristic skin changes.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.
  • • Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:
  • • Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:
  • • Myogenic response Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)
  • • Myogenic response
  • • Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)
  • • (TGF)
  • • 1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE
  • • 1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE
  • • Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases, → stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole → Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells → The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole → So, the blood flow is decreased.
  • • →
  • • →
  • • →
  • • →
  • • 2. TGF
  • • 2. TGF
  • • The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. NO : Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.
  • • Option A. NO
  • • Option B. Noradrenaline : Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.
  • • Option B. Noradrenaline
  • • Option D. Adenosine : Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.
  • • Option D. Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. SGLT1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. SGLT2 : Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.
  • • Option B. SGLT2
  • • Option C. GLUT4 : Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.
  • • Option C. GLUT4
  • • Option D. Na-Ca transporter : Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.
  • • Option
  • • D. Na-Ca transporter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: Which gene is commonly associated with the development of a round blue cell tumor in a child who underwent surgery for ocular malignancy? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rb gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rb gene mutation is responsible for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cretinism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female is brought to OPD with the following deformity. What can be inferred from this? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Genu Valgum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given question describes the genu valgum deformity (also called as knock knees). It is the abnormal approximation of the knees with abnormally divergent ankles.

questions.text: Methotrexate reduces the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TMP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to reduced synthesis of TMP by limiting tetrahydrofolate availability.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Superior vena cava

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: A young child had an episode of sore throat followed hematuria after 20 days. Which of the following is the implicated organism for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures of anthropometry? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weight-for-height

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wasting in a child is assessed using the weight-for-height measure, indicating acute malnutrition
  • ➤ Wasting
  • ➤ weight-for-height

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following about PEEP is true? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

options.label: D
options.text: Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.correct_answer: A. Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PEEP is primarily used to prevent alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and maintain lung recruitment, especially in conditions like ARDS or when the patient is positioned prone during mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.
